during an upgrade scenario, where the active controller is running N+1 and the standby is running prior release N (which may not have this support) will it be handled ok?

This code is only activated if SM fails and touches the RESET_PEER_NOW file on a controller when it detects that the active controller has stalled beyond its threshold.

The feature requires the mtcAgent to send the BMC info to the peer controller's mtcClient in advance of the event.

This means that both controllers need to have this change for it to take action.

So in the case you site the active controller might send the BMC info to the non-upgraded standby side only to be ignored because the info is represented as json data that is not keyed off of. So yes, this will be handled fine over an upgrade.

tools/collector/scripts/collect_disk.sh.message: New files can just have current date for copyright
This won't handle NVMe disks: /dev/nvme*n*. You should account for both.

You need to specify the TRAN field to be able to filter out the USB disks, otherwise the disk will still be present and smartctl will produce and error.

Also some disks may sit behind a raid controller which means to get all the disk information you'd need to specify some additional options:

   smartctl -a -d cciss,1 /dev/sda

I think you just need to update what you have to include all devices, removing usb disks, and then grabbing all remaining disks.

$ lsblk -l -o NAME,TYPE,TRAN
NAME        TYPE TRAN
sda         disk sata
sda1        part 
sdb         disk usb
sdb1        part 
sdb2        part 
sr0         rom  sata
nvme0n1     disk 
nvme0n1p1   part 
nvme0n1p2   part 
nvme0n1p3   part 
centos-root lvm  
centos-swap lvm  
centos-home lvm  

$ lsblk -l -o NAME,TYPE,TRAN | grep -v usb | grep -e disk
sda         disk sata
nvme0n1     disk

Bob, I did a ls /dev/ on a simplex and duplex but I didn't find anything related with /dev/nvme*.
With /dev/nvme*n* are you referring to /dev/nvme1, /dev/nvme2, and so on?
If it, I think I can do something like this:

RESULT1=`lsblk --scsi | grep sd | cut -d' ' -f1`
RESULT2=`ls /etc/nvme*`
RESULT3="$R1"" ""$R2"
for device in ${RESULT3}; do
    delimiter ${LOGFILE} "smartctl -a ${device}"
    smartctl -a "/dev/${device}" >> ${LOGFILE} 2>>${COLLECT_ERROR_LOG}
done

What do you think?

Shouldn't we have another script for the disks sited behind a raid controller?
I can't apply smartctl -a -d cciss,1 /dev/xxx command for my all results, it fails.

This is fine as it is now. It will gather additional information for most configurations. I mentioned it more for informational purposes. 

Depending on the H/W configuration you may find that this change will not report the physical details of the disk but the information that the raid controller present to the OS for the disk.

A future improvement could be made for this, if desired.

I'm thinking that these differences could be handled internally in sushy and exposed through the same property to accommodate both iDRAC and iLO (don't know about other vendor differences :)) as in the end it's the same thing. In that way there wouldn't be any additional processing in Ironic to use the right property.

> In case of iLO, there is no 'Location' header returned as part of response.

It surprises me to hear that iLO is not returning a Location header in a 202 response. Returning the Location header (the TaskMonitor opaque URI) is required by the spec for 202 responses. What does HPE say about this behavior? (do they plan to fix, etc.)

ok, I see. For iDRAC it's the same URI (Location header and Task's @odata.id) and there is no TaskMonitor property in Task.

sushy/resources/taskservice/taskmonitor..message: And on an HTTP Accepted, any content-length response is not required if I'm remembering correctly. I wonder why that was guarded... :\
'Content Length' Header is not passed by iLO. It seems not a must field when we get HTTP status  as 'ACCEPTED'. Also it was used as an extra check to see the operation was successful.

I believe this change is good to go. If there is not enough data for all of the fields in Task, the Task will be successfully constructed as long as its two (2) required fields, Id and Name, are present. And, if there is no body returned by the POST, its base class will GET it during __init__(). [1]

I have cc'd Chris Dearborn on this change, since he wrote the original code and added Aija Jaunteva as a reviewer, because she is also familiar with sushy.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/af4adf56a665ebf90ccff35e12d1228a4cf91c65/sushy/resources/base.py#L599

> The JsonDataReader GETs the resource using the `path` instance from the ResourceBase object. But in the case of the Task object, the path isn't passed in to its constructor because we do not have one.

Amending the above line from my previous comment a bit: I see that in the TaskMonitor constructor, the call to get_reader() passes in the the path of the TaskMonitor URI. So if and when the JsonDataReader calls GET to fetch the resource, it will do a GET on the TaskMonitor (not the Task resource). So again, if the Task resource is not included in the body of the 202 response from a GET on the TaskMonitor, the Task object cannot be created.

In other words, the JsonDataReader does have a `path` to do a GET on; it's just not the right path to get the Task resource.

In Redfish, when a 202 is returned, the response body should be an instance of the Task resource, but it does not have to be. It may be an empty body. And if the body is empty, a Task resource cannot be constructed.

So it seems like after this change we'll be trying to create a Task instance even if no body was returned (which I assume will raise an exception).

The problem here is that we don't have the Task URI available to GET in the case that the 202 response does not return a body.

The JsonDataReader GETs the resource using the `path` instance from the ResourceBase object. But in the case of the Task object, the path isn't passed in to its constructor because we do not have one.

iDRAC returns empty body with header Content-Length: 0.

The code as it is now should work as then it will go and fetch resource at `self._task_monitor` (that is URI although name is not indicated that).

However, without this change self._task remained set to None. Now it will be populated either from response Body or GETting from URI. Have to check if this somehow impacts workflow at Ironic.

specs/wallaby/security_service_update_im.message:
Alternative 1, proposed by gouthamr: if this can be an admin operation, we can do a 'security service migration' at share server level, by creating a new security service with the new configure and modifying each share server to the new sec. serv. Cons: works only for admin user. Pros: we can avoid a bunch of share server updates at the same time.

Alternative 2: a share-server periodic operation that checks if its share servers are outdated with their security service configuration. We can add a versioning or use the last_updated time to check for outdated configs. We still can block a security service of being updated if at least one share server doesn't support this functionality.

... but I think we might be reclaimable almost immediatley if we're re-using the root's timestamp or we might not get deleted at all if we still have rows

yeah that was kinda the plan. if the root is reclaimed then do we need the shards, seeing as there is a strong relationship. Ie a root + shards conceptually are the same container.

BUT I did have a thought last night. shards are created all the time. Is there a chance that a shard was created (a shard cleaved on a shard) after the root is marked as deleted. In this case it'll maen the delete timestamp is before a put timestamp and wont be deleted.. tho having said that, in that case we might be able to take advantage of using time.time() once the root is reclaimed (not sure it'll work like that in the current code tho).

we want 404s to come back and get processed, turns out this only happens after the root is reclaimed because we send X-Backend-Override-Deleted so we can still get shards out of roots marked as deleted.
opps forgot to fix this. That'll be in the next patchset.
we could always use a Time.time() here, but then shards that haven't cleaned themselves up will live an extra reclaim_age.
I wonder if the method could be broken out into two steps - first get the response, second parse the shard ranges from response? rather than returning the tuple?...

...in fact the remainder looks a lot like https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/077ba77ea6f735c98709b60e1fc9aa9f0f90676a/swift/proxy/controllers/base.py#L2308 so maybe can re-use as a utils helper method?
... first get a response and do the delete-related stuff...
does this need to be a function vs a bool var?

then parse the shards using something like _parse_shard_ranges() 

hmmm, _parse_shard_ranges() takes a req arg...but IDK, maybe it can be refactored, definitely seems like there is scope to have some code re-use

The real question is should we attempt this and get nice quick cleanups for be safe and use:

  Timestamp.now().internal

if the question is simply 'should we be safe or not' then be safe 😊

but, what's the risk? that the root appears to have been deleted for reclaim_age, but in fact has not yet been reclaimed (quite possible) and the shard deletes itself prematurely? I'd vote for being safe in this instance because this fix should ultimately be the backstop (i.e. once we have shrinking, getting here should be exceptional, so play it really safe)

neutron/services/portforwarding/drivers/.message:
Shouldn't be this update something to be handled by the PF plugin (PortForwardingPlugin)? This should happen in any case, regardless of the driver (OVN, OVS, etc). Why should the OVN take care of this?

Maybe I'm missing something here.

for ovs driver,  the PF plugin notifies the L3 agent, and after L3 agent pf extenstion processing, call rpc set floatingip status.
the ovn driver gets the processing results synchronously, and the ovs driver is asynchronous. Therefore, the floatingip status cannot be updated in PF plugin.

Thanks!

It looks better to update the status in the plugin layer rather than the driver layer.
If a driver reports a success, the plugin can update the status.

It is possible that the floating IP contains multiple PFs, and delete one this time.

> tl;dr: this potential problem exists before this patch, so the fix needs to be done independently and also potentially the fix needs to be backported to affected stable branches.
> 

Gibi, thanks for helping check this, we can moving forward with later fix now 😊

> Long answer:
> This is complicated, if self.compute_rpcapi.unshelve_instance() call fails in certain reasons the the compute manager deletes the allocation [1] and the reraise the exception making the allocatino delete here unnecessary. 
> 
> BUT I can imagine that there are cases when such delete is not triggered. E.g.:
> * we fail to send the RPC so the unshelve_instance RPC handler in the compute manager is not even called
> * the RPC reaches the compute manager but an exception is raised before the try block  in the compute manager. E.g. instance.save()[2] fails due to intermittent db or network failure. Then the exception bubbles up to here without any allocation delete.
> 

I'm not worry about those case, in those cases, the instance should be stuck at UNSHELVING state, so the user doesn't have anything can do then delete it, after instance being delete, the allocation will be cleanup.

But yes, this isn't prefect for UX, we should allow the user unshelve the instance again, but that is also another topic.
Maybe you are right, it's better to deallocate the resources from placement here rather in ``compute.unshelve_instance()``, but we can fix this later.

tl;dr: this potential problem exists before this patch, so the fix needs to be done independently and also potentially the fix needs to be backported to affected stable branches.

Long answer:
This is complicated, if self.compute_rpcapi.unshelve_instance() call fails in certain reasons the the compute manager deletes the allocation [1] and the reraise the exception making the allocatino delete here unnecessary. 

BUT I can imagine that there are cases when such delete is not triggered. E.g.:
* we fail to send the RPC so the unshelve_instance RPC handler in the compute manager is not even called
* the RPC reaches the compute manager but an exception is raised before the try block  in the compute manager. E.g. instance.save()[2] fails due to intermittent db or network failure. Then the exception bubbles up to here without any allocation delete.



[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e6f5e814050a19d6f027037424556b2889514ec3/nova/compute/manager.py#L6594
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e6f5e814050a19d6f027037424556b2889514ec3/nova/compute/manager.py#L6541

Yes. Starting with microversion 2.53, we can use the 'hypervisor_hostname_pattern' querystring parameter to either '/os-hypervisors' or '/os-hypervisors/detail'. That explicitly errors out if these are specified [1]. Prior to microversion 2.53, we had to us a separate  '/os-hypervisors/search/{hypervisor_hostname_pattern}' endpoint. That ignores the pagination information entirely [1]. As such, this is a fair thing to state.

Note that the 'search' library API from novaclient we're using below automatically switches between these endpoints [3] based on the microversion so we don't need to do this ourselves.

service-mgmt/sm/src/sm_cluster_hbs_info_.message: you want this log on every 'process' of cluster info that reports sm heartbeat fail reading ?

What critical information is in this log ?

It only logs when a hbs cluster update is received. There are 2 cases to receive hbs cluster update, a. a hbs cluster state change detected by hbsAgent, b. SM queries hbsAgent when a failure is detected. The log won't flood the log file.
This will just make the concern for log flooding even worse. Are there no words you can put in the log below that will make it 'stand out' enough for you ?

This is an alarming situation, peer SM does not heartbeat to hbsAgent in time. It is not an error condition as the heartbeat between SM is still alive, it is not set to a warning or error log. But it needs some attentions.

This is not an error or warning. The SM heartbeat is still alive. It is not expected to happen repeatedly, as it is part of hbs cluster info state change or query. I don't think throttling is needed.
Is this expected or should this be an ERROR log?
This is not an error. From SM point of view, the heartbeat is fine at this time.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
If we are going to configure cert-manager to use the 'deployment' namespace, is there any reason that the cert-manager app/chart doesn't set this up as part of applying the application? 

If so, we can avoid a playbook changes.

The context here is not that cert-manager needs the 'deployment' namespace.  The context is that any data managed by the Deployment Manager (DM) should be in the 'deployment' namespace.  So 'deployment' namespace should be a namespace that always exists.  

E.g. in the case of platform certificates (secrets and certificates resources), in the DM scenario these will get created in 'deployment' namespace.  In non-DM scenario, we wanted to have the platform certificates in the same place ... i.e. have the user create them in the 'deployment' namespace.

This was discussed with Don & Matt ... I'll add them to the review.

Understood. But why wouldn't the cert-manager app/chart create it if it needs to manage it? Why would it require something external to create the namespace it needs/wants?

For example, platform-integ-apps supports creating additional namespaces that will be required besides the namespace that it is installed.

I just took a look at sysinv code and it appears that there's existing support for multiple namespaces creation per app. In that case, your suggested solution is preferred.

I wonder if the dc-cert namespace should also be created the same way.

The deployment namespace is not just under the cert-manager's control. It's a generic namespace created that is (and will continue) to be used by other resources in the system. Creating this in ansible is the appropriate place for it.
My thought was that it would be part of a chart included in the cert-manager app. Just asking Q's here, not trying to block submission.
I believe cert-manager namespace is already created during the apply of the app. This namespace is meant to be a separate namespace for platform certificates managed by the cert-manager.
In this case, ns creation during bootstrap is appropriate.

@Bob & @Tee, would that mean creation of namespace through the app's helm chart (i.e., in stx-cert-manager-helm/manifests) or would it be somewhere in the sysinv code?

I guess it doesnt matter where it is created as long as the namespace is present after system bootstrap. So, if that leads to cleaner design and removes any reservations about upgrades/restores, I could move it there.

It was fixed in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ansible-collections-openstack/+/764046
We have min_ver option for arguments to limit versions of usage
It's not correct, you can see result from rocky job, it doesn't fail. 0.17.4 version

Looking at 'ci/roles/volume/tasks/volume_info.yml' it looks like there is currently no unit test that runs for sdk 0.17.4 and is not 'ignore_errors: true'. The second test ('Get info about volumes for all SDK') does not fail because it returns no volumes at all ([]).

In the latest patchset I have removed the sdk check that prevented test execution with older sdk versions. Let's see how that works out..

An empty result is (and was) okay, because then nothing has to be converted or interpreted. But if you do get non-empty results, then you have to use to_dict() for older sdk versions. Since 0.19, the object that 'self.conn.block_storage.volumes()' returns is a subclass of dict and therefore Ansible can read its content (to_dict is not necessary anymore).

The unit test for volume_info does not trigger this bug, because the only test that is run on sdk<0.28 returns an empty result.

I did upload a new patch that might be a bit more pythonic.

It does not check for a specific sdk version but instead just tests whether the result from openstacksdk is a dict (post 0.19) or not (pre 0.19). 

Without this (or the older) patch, the module will fail on older sdk versions because the result of 'volumes()' is not a list of dict's and hence Ansible does not know what to do.
So empty result might be a problem that should be solved by your patch with to_dict() ?

releasenotes/notes/add-prometheus-v2-9f1.message:
Needs some more details:

* What is the new flag?
* is it enabled by default?
* what to do if you want to keep using v1?
* can I migrate to v2?
Should we also say that v1 is deprecated here and will be removed in the following release? It's very hard to imagine a good reason to use it :)

I suppose the reason would be that you are already using it and don't have a path to migrate your data to v2. We need to decide to either provide that migration path, support both forever, or leave it up to users to migrate and drop v1.

Let's drop v1 - it's a dead piece of software, with unknown count of security holes that would never get patched. As for the volume removal feature - it may be not worth implementing it for a single use case - maybe multiple ones? Like removing all not mounted volumes some time after the upgrade or letting user choose what should be cleaned up. In case of Prometheus, it should be sufficient to say that the old volume is left behind - can be deleted easily in a manual way, otherwise it stays forever.

My vote is for letting users migrate and save development effort for improving monitoring out of the box. I think many people will be retaining only 2 weeks of data and won't be overly concerned about migrating it. For users not happy with that, I suppose with this patch, a simple option to view old data would be to manually spin up a v1 container and mount the old volume in and add some custom HAProxy config for multinode deployments.

Can we log the warning from the docs when a caller uses this to swap volumes?

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=update-a-volume-attachment-detail#update-a-volume-attachment

"When updating volumeId, this API is typically meant to only be used as part of a larger orchestrated volume migration operation initiated in the block storage service via the os-retype or os-migrate_volume volume actions. Direct usage of this API to update volumeId is not recommended and may result in needing to hard reboot the server to update details within the guest such as block storage serial IDs. Furthermore, updating volumeId via this API is only implemented by certain compute drivers."

As discussed on IRC, I've dropped this an only retained the updating of the delete-on-termination flag.

Either novaclient or nova itself could do with some work though. It seems silly to have to provide the volume ID twice now. Potential future microversion

can we do this as a boolean instead

--delete-on-termination=True|False default None/unset

i dont really like apis that use --no* for negation
the normally dont read correctly.

"delete on termination" is an imperative statement

"no delete on termination" is not and is grammatically incorrect, it should be

"no deletetion on termination", "preserve on termination" or  "do not delete on termination"

hence my preference to have it be a boolean so that it becomes a question.
The no prefix is a common cisco idiom so its well know but that does not make it a good experence.

if you want to key it as too independent flags i would use "--preserve-on-termination" instead.
Definitely not a fan of doing a boolean option. '--foo True' is considered bad UX and not something we allow in OSC. However, the '--preserve-on-termination' is a good idea. I'll use that.
well that is subjective i consider having two independ parmaters bad ux espaically from a scripting point of view but since we are both ok with --preserve-on-termination we are all good.
Well there's your mistake 😊 OSC is intended for humans, not scripting. It can do that, but openstacksdk and novaclient are better suited for programmatic interactions.

no that was the point of osc's stance on microverions
it was intened to proved a stable sriptable cli.

the approch taken by the python client is for better or worse more human friendly.
osc was always intened to be scripting friendly.

specs/wallaby/add-security-service-in-us.message:
Is it possible to combine this specification with the other one that seeks to allow updating a security service? If not, why?

three actions that aren't supported today, but could be evolved with a consistent user experience can be:

1) Adding one or more security services to a share network in use, and
2) Updating an existing security service from a share network that's in use
3) Removing a security service from a share network that's in use


To provide that consistent user experience, we also need to distinguish between backends that can and cannot support this feature so that expectations can be deterministic. That is:

The user could be allowed to know if they can or cannot update their share network security services before hand - perhaps through the share type as a capability? or by inspecting a used share network (the share type capability could be copied over to the share network).

If update can't be supported, we'd fail all three operations above fast. We wouldn't allow user workloads from a given share network to span backends that have different levels of support for mutable security services - yet another aspect of deterministic design. WDYT?

These proposals (and associated changes) can stay separate if we believe backends actually can't offer security service configuration updates as well as new security service reconfigurations at the same time. I know you're not proposing a solution for problem (3), but I want to bring it up here for completeness.

Thank you Goutham for adding these notes and concerns.

Yes, it is possible to merge both specs, since they are converging to be share-network operations. 

About 'removing security service': - The idea was to not include the removal operation, since it can be dangerous and lead to scenario that can be hard to be reverted; Admins may not be able to recover from this failure so easily. Make sense? Do you think that is mandatory to have this operation too? Both Add and Update should cover almost all user scenarios so far. 

Capabilities: I believe that we can rely in a single back end capability, since update and add are very analogous operations.

I will start to merge and fix all comments within this spec and will get back to you guys if I found any gap with the new 'share-network' approach for both updating and adding security service.

By allowing the update at share-network granularity we may mitigate lots of share server updates at once and have a more phased operation.
nit: allow

reflecting?

Is there a reason the script is placed in /tmp? It seems like it might get accidentally removed from there.
Is there an issue that this fixes?

There is ongoing issue where archiving directory is getting full on multiple sites because archiving does not have any deletion mechanism. Archiving was introduced to solve issue of postgres xlog directory filling up with WAL(write ahead log) files but those WAL logs also contain MAAS node status which fills up archiving in long run (~month). This change is essential to avoid that issue.

postgresql/templates/bin/_postgresql_arc.message: this seems excessive to run this every minute until the server terminates.
Most of the bash we use is 2 space delimited, can we have this file follow the same format as well.
We reference this in values.yaml, why not use that similar to ARCHIVE_LIMIT here.

We want to safeguard against memory issue but still the archiving helps in PITR (point in time recovery). Postgres has mechanism which will unpack these zipped WAL files and use them to automatically recover in case of crash. Script is adjusted to keep 30-60 % default archiving which helps in PITR without risk of running into memory issues.

postgresql/templates/bin/_start.sh.tpl.message: why background here? it's not supposed to take long and since we get no time benefit - lets keep it simpler

It is done in background since this check is ran continuously every hour for the lifetime of pod. If we just execute the cleanup script without &, bash script execution would not move to next line which starts up postgres DB.

There is no guarantee that previous sonobuoy install script actually installed the sonobuoy binary. So, it would be wise to check if the binary exists before running the command since all of this is run as part of the zuul job sequence with no human intervention. You need to exit the script and also the zuul execution with a proper error message if the binary does not exist.

The sonobuoy version command is also there 
in the previous script in place to make sure that sonobuoy gets installed properly.

If the first installation script fails, the zuul gate will fail. The second script is not going to execute.

And in case if the binary does not exist, this script will
fail saying sonobuoy binary not found.
 


```
sudo install -m 755 -o root /tmp/sonobuoy/sonobuoy /usr/local/bin
echo ${KUBECONFIG}

sonobuoy version --kubeconfig ${KUBECONFIG}
```

senlin/drivers/os/keystone_v3.py.message:
This method is called from different places in Senlin but usually the return value of this method is not directly passed to the openstack sdk Connection.  Instead it is wrapped by another dictionary that is eventually passed to the openstack sdk Connection constructor.  E.g. see https://github.com/openstack/senlin/blob/master/senlin/api/middleware/webhook.py#L56
In that example, certain keys are taken from return value of the get_service_credentials call and put inside another dictionary called kwargs.  The kwargs dictionary is then passed to _get_token which calls the openstack SDK Connection constructor down the line.

In order for the 'verify' and 'interface' keys to get passed to Openstack SDK, all the calls to get_service_credentials need to be checked and those keys need to be extracted as well to be passed on.

For rook, it deploy mon, like mon-a, mon-b, mon-c ..., depends on your mon number.

For example /var/lib/ceph/mon-a on controller-0, and /var/lib/ceph/mon-b on controller-1. After controller-0 is restored, pod mon-a read mon-data from restored folder. When pod mon-b launched on controller-1, if there is no folder /var/lib/ceph/mon-b, create a blank folder and sync mon data from controller-0. Folder /var/lib/ceph/mon-a will be unused.

config.yaml.message: Are there other drivers that the charm supports? Typically, if other drivers come into play they are modeled slightly differently in the charms (i.e. we will have a subordinate charm to enable a driver - see charm-cinder-ceph as an example) as there are various config items that are relevant to that driver.

The only supported driver per my understanding is the Dibbler driver.  Other drivers very well may need additional configuration so it would make sense to me to separate that out.  I can absolutely pull that out for the time being as it was not part of the original requirements.  

Maybe I shouldn't have tried and maybe I wouldn't have gone over par 😊

I didn't find much detail on other drivers in doc searches. Some code searches in upstream neutron code would be worthwhile to see what other drivers are available. Ideally there would be a single driver that we could use as the default for now. And if we grew support for other drivers in the future then we could deal with it then. The upstream dibbler code seems to not be maintained anymore so that's something to evaluate. But if that is the default driver for neutron then you have to assume it's good enough. Have you checked with narindergupta (he opened the bug)? I wonder if he is knowledgable on the topic. We also need to get with someone familiar with deploying ipv6 and get access to an environment where this can be tested. I'm not sure we can test on serverstack.
